articles.headline: The End of Cheap Chinese Goods
articles.snippet: Apparel prices, which fell in the last 10 years and then stabilized, have begun to increase.
articles.abstract: Apparel prices, which fell in the last 10 years and then stabilized, have begun to increase.
articles.lead_paragraph: The great Chinese-led deflation in goods prices may have come to an end.

articles.headline: Volcker Rule, Once Simple, Now Boggles
articles.snippet: Many people across the political spectrum do not support the Volcker Rule as it is now written — including Paul Volcker.
articles.abstract: Many people across the political spectrum do not support the Volcker Rule as it is now written — including Paul Volcker.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Paul Volcker called for new rules in 2009 to curb risk-taking by banks, and thus avoid making taxpayers liable in the future for the kind of reckless speculation that caused the financial crisis and resulting bailout, he outlined his proposal in a three-page letter to the president.

articles.headline: U.S. Troops to Leave Iraq by Year’s End, Obama Says
articles.snippet: The decision will draw to a close a divisive war that cost the lives of more than 4,400 troops and helped ignite President Obama’s rise.
articles.abstract: The decision will draw to a close a divisive war that cost the lives of more than 4,400 troops and helped ignite President Obama’s rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced on Friday that the last American soldier would leave Iraq by the end of this year, drawing to a close a divisive eight-year war that cost the lives of more than 4,400 troops, defined the presidency of George W. Bush, and helped ignite his own political rise.

articles.headline: BP’s Plan for Drilling in the Gulf Is Approved
articles.snippet: The Obama administration approved the first oil drilling plan for the company in the Gulf of Mexico since an explosion sank the Deepwater Horizon rig more than a year ago.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration approved the first oil drilling plan for the company in the Gulf of Mexico since an explosion sank the Deepwater Horizon rig more than a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Obama administration on Friday took another step toward allowing BP to return to the Gulf of Mexico, approving the first oil drilling plan for the company there since the explosion that sank the Deepwater Horizon rig more than a year ago.

articles.headline: Retirement Funds Built for Skittish Times
articles.snippet: A new kind of target-date fund from Pimco puts less money in stocks, offers more inflation protection and invests in hedges to protect against large losses.
articles.abstract: A new kind of target-date fund from Pimco puts less money in stocks, offers more inflation protection and invests in hedges to protect against large losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: You must unlearn what you have learned.

articles.headline: At Annual Meeting, Murdoch Spars With Investors
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch apologized for the hacking scandal and defended the company’s leadership.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch apologized for the hacking scandal and defended the company’s leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite fiery attacks from shareholders, Rupert Murdoch and the rest of the News Corporation board were re-elected on Friday, after a turbulent summer during which a phone-hacking scandal in Britain prompted a rising level of discontent among investors.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Death of Qaddafi Revives Opposition, and Hope, in Syria
articles.snippet: The Syrian National Council has closed ranks in the most concerted attempt yet to forge an alternative to President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.abstract: The Syrian National Council has closed ranks in the most concerted attempt yet to forge an alternative to President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi reverberated across Syria on Friday, reviving protests that had begun to stall and focusing attention on a newly organized, unarmed opposition group seeking to challenge the Assad family’s four decades of rule.

articles.headline: Seeing Limits to ‘New’ Kind of War in Libya
articles.snippet: The United States remains the backbone of any NATO offensive, even while “leading from behind.”
articles.abstract: The United States remains the backbone of any NATO offensive, even while “leading from behind.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all its success, NATO’s intervention in Libya had several significant flaws that highlight why future offensives, against a stronger adversary, could be far more difficult.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Out From Behind the Counter
articles.snippet: Trying to build a large health care role for itself, the Walgreen Company is giving its pharmacists more time and opportunity to counsel patients in the aisles.
articles.abstract: Trying to build a large health care role for itself, the Walgreen Company is giving its pharmacists more time and opportunity to counsel patients in the aisles.

articles.headline: Wall St. Protest Isn’t Like Ours, Tea Party Says
articles.snippet: Where Occupy Wall Street and the Tea Party differ is in where they place the blame.
articles.abstract: Where Occupy Wall Street and the Tea Party differ is in where they place the blame.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a Republican candidate forum outside Fort Worth last week, a Tea Party activist turned Senate candidate proclaimed the Occupy Wall Street protesters “unemployed, uneducated and uninformed.” To which the conservative radio host moderating the panel added, mirthfully, “This is the first occupation many of these people have seen in years.”

articles.headline: How Mr. Volcker Would Fix It
articles.snippet: Paul Volcker, the former Fed chairman, says crucial work must still be done to make consumers, investors and the economy safer.
articles.abstract: Paul Volcker, the former Fed chairman, says crucial work must still be done to make consumers, investors and the economy safer.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMID all the minutiae of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul, it’s easy to lose sight of the big question: will consumers, investors and the economy be safer?

articles.headline: Unreasonable, Maybe, but It’s on a Social Mission
articles.snippet: The Unreasonable Institute in Colorado offers a six-week course to entrepreneurs who want to make a profit while helping the world.
articles.abstract: The Unreasonable Institute in Colorado offers a six-week course to entrepreneurs who want to make a profit while helping the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: DANIEL EPSTEIN wants to get one thing straight: He is an unreasonable man. Happily, proudly unreasonable. Entrepreneurs who want to change the world, he says, have got to be a little crazy.

articles.headline: The Little State With a Big Mess
articles.snippet: After decades of drift, denial and inaction, Rhode Island’s $14.8 billion pension system is in crisis. And its outcome could be a portent for other states.
articles.abstract: After decades of drift, denial and inaction, Rhode Island’s $14.8 billion pension system is in crisis. And its outcome could be a portent for other states.
articles.lead_paragraph: CRANSTON, R.I.

articles.headline: In His Last Days, Qaddafi Wearied of Fugitive’s Life
articles.snippet: After 42 years of absolute power in Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi spent his last days hovering between defiance, anger and delusion, surviving on rice and pasta, according to an aide captured with him.
articles.abstract: After 42 years of absolute power in Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi spent his last days hovering between defiance, anger and delusion, surviving on rice and pasta, according to an aide captured with him.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISURATA, Libya — After 42 years of absolute power in Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi spent his last days hovering between defiance and delusion, surviving on rice and pasta his guards scrounged from the emptied civilian houses he moved between every few days, according to a senior security official captured with him.

articles.headline: Bank’s Collapse in Europe Points to Global Risks
articles.snippet: As much as American financial institutions have sought to minimize damage from Europe’s problems, the rescue of Dexia shows that there may be risks that are less known.
articles.abstract: As much as American financial institutions have sought to minimize damage from Europe’s problems, the rescue of Dexia shows that there may be risks that are less known.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Europe’s debt crisis has deepened, a recurring question is how much risk it poses to the United States economy, and especially American banks.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story

articles.headline: A Silicon Valley School That Doesn’t Compute
articles.snippet: The Waldorf School’s computer-free environment has become a draw for parents at high-tech companies like Google.
articles.abstract: The Waldorf School’s computer-free environment has become a draw for parents at high-tech companies like Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ALTOS, Calif. — The chief technology officer of eBay sends his children to a nine-classroom school here. So do employees of Silicon Valley giants like Google, Apple, Yahoo and Hewlett-Packard.

articles.headline: Cain, Now Running as Outsider, Came to Washington as Lobbyist
articles.snippet: The role that helped propel Herman Cain into politics was that of an ultimate Washington insider: industry lobbyist.
articles.abstract: The role that helped propel Herman Cain into politics was that of an ultimate Washington insider: industry lobbyist.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Herman Cain, the Republican presidential candidate with the sharp wit and easy-to-remember tax plan, is a cancer survivor, radio host and former chief executive of Godfather’s Pizza. On the campaign trail, he talks up his business experience, casting himself as a “problem solver” and Washington outsider.

articles.headline: Tunisians Vote in a Milestone of Arab Change
articles.snippet: Millions of Tunisians stood in lines to vote for an assembly to draft a new constitution, expressing confidence that their small country could now lead the way to democracy.
articles.abstract: Millions of Tunisians stood in lines to vote for an assembly to draft a new constitution, expressing confidence that their small country could now lead the way to democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Millions of Tunisians cast votes on Sunday for an assembly to draft a constitution and shape a new government, in a burst of pride and hope that after inspiring uprisings across the Arab world, their small country could now lead the way to democracy.

articles.headline: European Leaders Deal Directly With Debt Dilemma
articles.snippet: Leaders hope the seriousness of their effort to solve the problems of Greek debt, weak banks and a bailout fund in need of reinforcement will ease the markets on Monday.
articles.abstract: Leaders hope the seriousness of their effort to solve the problems of Greek debt, weak banks and a bailout fund in need of reinforcement will ease the markets on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With a new sense of urgency, the leaders of the 27 European Union nations grappled directly on Sunday with their thorniest financial and economic problems, and made progress that they promised could yield a complete package of measures within days.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Republicans Turn Judicial Power Into a Campaign Issue
articles.snippet: G.O.P. presidential candidates are issuing attacks on the federal courts, stoking skepticism among conservatives about the judiciary.
articles.abstract: G.O.P. presidential candidates are issuing attacks on the federal courts, stoking skepticism among conservatives about the judiciary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican presidential candidates are issuing biting and sustained attacks on the federal courts and the role they play in American life, reflecting and stoking skepticism among conservatives about the judiciary.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Apple’s Lower Prices Are All Part of the Plan
articles.snippet: Apple is using its scale and prowess to deliver products at more aggressive prices, giving it more industry power.
articles.abstract: Apple is using its scale and prowess to deliver products at more aggressive prices, giving it more industry power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something unexpected has happened at Apple, once known as the tech industry’s high-price leader. Over the last several years it began beating rivals on price.

articles.headline: In a Gloomy Economy, TV Sitcoms Are Making a Comeback
articles.snippet: After years of dramas and reality shows, television’s pendulum appears to be swinging toward the laugh track.
articles.abstract: After years of dramas and reality shows, television’s pendulum appears to be swinging toward the laugh track.
articles.lead_paragraph: In television, funny is money again.

articles.headline: Why Not Occupy Newsrooms?
articles.snippet: Media companies offer their own prime examples of the bonus excess that is driving the protests at Occupy Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Media companies offer their own prime examples of the bonus excess that is driving the protests at Occupy Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost two weeks ago, USA Today put its finger on why the Occupy Wall Street protests continued to gain traction.

articles.headline: Panetta’s Pentagon, Without the Blank Check
articles.snippet: Leon E. Panetta, the new defense secretary, must balance military cuts against a national security threats.
articles.abstract: Leon E. Panetta, the new defense secretary, must balance military cuts against a national security threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tan and ruddy-faced, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta took his seat in a hearing room one morning this month ready for battle. The enemy, he warned lawmakers ominously, was “a blind, mindless” one that could “badly damage our capabilities” and “truly devastate our national defense.”

articles.headline: Investors Wait Warily for Europe Bank Rescue
articles.snippet: Investors fear that the bank rescue plan being negotiated by European officials will not be large enough to solve the problems stemming from the sovereign debt crisis.
articles.abstract: Investors fear that the bank rescue plan being negotiated by European officials will not be large enough to solve the problems stemming from the sovereign debt crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: After negotiating through the weekend in Brussels in search of a comprehensive solution to the Continent’s sovereign debt crisis, European leaders reported progress on the framework of a broad rescue package.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Evelyn M. Rusli

articles.headline: Slaughter of Horses Goes On, Just Not in U.S.
articles.snippet: A new government study raises questions about whether horses have been helped by a federal policy that led to the closure of slaughterhouses for horses.
articles.abstract: A new government study raises questions about whether horses have been helped by a federal policy that led to the closure of slaughterhouses for horses.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — The closing of the country’s last meat processing plant that slaughtered horses for human consumption was hailed as a victory for equine welfare. But five years later just as many American horses are destined for dinner plates to satisfy the still robust appetites for their meat in Europe and Asia.
